awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Enhanced Plasma deposition Process for MgO-Based Magnetic Tunnel Junctions with 500% Magnetoresistance
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will develop the process to fabricate magnesium-oxide (MgO) based magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) sensor devices, which are simultaneously ultra-sensitive at high frequencies, small in size, with high output, and extremely low power consumption. The dual advantages of high sensitivity and low power consumption will separate these sensor devices from traditional Hall-effect and magnetoresistive sensor products, which are power hungry and typically not suitable for many high-performance and battery-powered sensing applications. This innovative approach combines the high resistivity tunneling and enhanced signal strength derived from magnesium oxide tunnel barrier technology. 

The broader impact anticipated if this project is realized is a new class of MgO-based sensors with high sensitivity and low power consumption, and the development of a reliable fabrication process suitable for mass production. This project will advance the state of understanding of the emerging spintronic technology of magnetic tunnel junctions, a class of devices which forms the central component of a number of important commercial products in the high-tech semiconductor and data storage industries. Finally, the collaboration of physicists, electrical engineers, materials scientists, and students will result in a broader multidisciplinary training and education for all the participants in the field of spintronics.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project has lead to a fabrication process for high performance magnetic sensor devices. Under the support of this SBIR award, Micro Magnetics has developed a process of fabricating MgO-based magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) sensor devices. These sensors are simultaneously ultra-sensitive (1 nT/Hz1/2 at 1 Hz, ~0.1 nT/Hz1/2 at high frequencies), small in size (<1 mm2 total die size), with high output (60 mV/G at 12V), and extremely low power consumption (25 µW). The dual advantages of high sensitivity and low power consumption separate these sensor devices from traditional Hall-effect and magnetoresistive sensor products, which are power hungry and therefore not suitable for many high-performance and battery-powered sensing applications. Our solution combines the dual innovations of high resistivity tunneling and enhanced signal strength derived from magnesium oxide tunnel barrier technology.

 

The realization of MgO-based sensors with high sensitivity and low power consumption and the development of a reliable fabrication process suitable for mass production have a variety of economical and societal impacts. Most importantly, it has created a new product with greatly enhanced capabilities for use in many critical segments of America’s sensor market, including remote sensing applications in the defense and homeland security segments, current measurement devices in high voltage power lines and a number of emerging medical applications. This Phase II effort has advanced the state of understanding of the emerging spintronic technology of magnetic tunnel junctions, a class of devices which forms the central component of a number of important commercial products in the high-tech semiconductor and data storage industries. Our research has enhanced our understanding in micromagnetics and coherent spin-dependent tunneling. Finally, the collaboration of physicists, electrical engineers, materials scientists, and students has resulted in a broader multidisciplinary training and education for all the participants in the project. 

 


Last Modified: 04/23/2013
Modified by: Matthew J Carter
